passage_text: Analgesics are those drugs that mainly provide pain relief. The primary classes of analgesics are the narcotics, including additional agents that are chemically based on the morphine molecule but have minimal abuse potential; nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) including the salicylates; and acetaminophen.

Ancient analgesics included the leaves and bark of willow trees. Morphine is an analgesic used to treat chronic pain. An ice pack, which can be used as a topical analgesic. Acetaminophen might be considered an analgesic that treats pain without addressing its source. Some narcotic analgesics are derived from opium. Salicylic acid is derived from willow bark.
Analgesia is the relief of pain, and an analgesic is something designed to relieve pain, usually in some drug used to combat swelling or aches.

An analgesic or painkiller is any member of the group of drugs used to achieve analgesia, relief from pain. Analgesic drugs act in various ways on the peripheral and central nervous systems. They are distinct from anesthetics, which reversibly eliminate sensation.

Analgesics are drugs that can relieve pain, but not inflammation, in people with arthritis and other chronic conditions. Acetaminophen (Tylenol) is available without a prescription. Opioid analgesics are available only with
